data.title: Sunburn for 6.22.17 â€” Postcard from the City Beautiful; Rick Scott vs. Conn; Corcoran PAC brings in the bucks; More endorsements for Ashley Moody; New Game of Thrones trailer drops
data.meta_description: Sunburn â€” The morning read of whatâ€™s hot in Florida politics. By Peter Schorsch, Phil Ammann, Jenna Buzzacco-Foerster, Mitch Perry and Jim Rosica. Good
data.meta_site_name: Florida Politics - Campaigns & Elections. Lobbying & Government.
data.text:
Sunburn â€” The morning read of whatâ€™s hot in Florida politics.

By Peter Schorsch, Phil Ammann, Jenna Buzzacco-Foerster, Mitch Perry and Jim Rosica.

Good morning from the City Beautiful. Iâ€™ve spent the last three days in Orlando presenting to two groups of hedge fund managers and analysts (all of whom were very interested in Sunshine State politics) as well as meeting with several elected officials and candidates.

I also spent time interviewing Democratic gubernatorial candidate Chris King who may just be the most telegenic statewide candidate weâ€™ve seen since Charlie Crist was a state Senator challenging Bob Graham. The up-and-comer did not win that race against one of the most storied names in modern Florida history, just as King is up against a formidable opponent who also has Graham as her last name. But like Crist circa 1998, the young man bears watching.

***Todayâ€™s SUNBURN is brought to you by Spectrum Reach, the marketing platform of choice, connecting you to your target audience on TV, digital and mobile. With access to our powerful data and insights, solutions for every screen, and the best programming content on the top 50+ networks, weâ€™ll help you reach the right customers for your business. SpectrumReach.com #NeverStopReaching***

â€” SCOTT WORLD â€”

The stateâ€™s leading LGBTQ-rights organization says Gov. Rick Scott went back on his word that heâ€™d sign an executive order protecting lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and other state employees from discrimination.

Leaders of Equality Florida said they met with the governorâ€™s staff days after last yearâ€™s Pulse nightclub shootings in Orlando, and were told staff â€œneeded a few weeksâ€ to draft the language. Nothing happened.

Now, the organization and the Florida Democratic Party are tired of waiting.

â€œIn the wake of an unprecedented tragedy, Rick Scott made commitments to protect LGBTQ Floridians in the workplace so they can earn a living without fear of discrimination or losing their job,â€ FDP spokesperson Johanna Cervone said in a statement.

â€œNow Scott is breaking those promises. Rick Scott talks a big game about jobs, but doesnâ€™t seem to care about LGBTQ Floridians trying to make a living.â€

Added Hannah Willard, public policy director of Equality Florida: â€œIt seems if there was ever a moment for him to issue an executive order, it was then, and by failing to do so, we now want to publicly hold him accountable for not taking meaningful action to protect LGBTQ people in Florida.â€

An executive order wouldnâ€™t go as far as The Florida Competitive Workforce Act, however.

Thatâ€™s the bill that has come before the Legislature every year since 2010. It would prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity or expression in employment, housing and public accommodations.

â€œFlorida is a state that does not tolerate discrimination of any form,â€ Scott spokeswoman Lauren Schenone told FloridaPolitics.com.

â€œIn accordance with federal guidelines, Florida state agencies do not discriminate on the basis of sexual orientation, and state employees should not be discriminated against in any way,â€ she added. â€œOur office will continue to review ways we can work to eliminate discrimination of any kind.â€

Meantime, proposals filed with the Constitution Revision Commission, the body reviewing the stateâ€™s governing document, have several versions of general anti-discrimination language intended as amendments.

One proposal would prohibit discrimination â€œin housing, employment, or services based upon race, country of origin, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, disability â€¦â€

But given the overarching conservative makeup of that panel, and the fact that CRC Chair Carlos Beruff was appointed by and is closely aligned with Scott, a constitutional fix seems even less likely than a statutory one.

â€œConnecticut newspaper to Scott: â€˜go back to Florida and stay thereâ€™â€ via Katie Sanders of the Miami Herald â€” Scott told a small crowd in Norfolk, Connecticut, to â€œgo ahead and give up â€¦ capitulate, and come to Florida and make it easier on yourselves,â€ and not stay in Connecticut with its higher income taxes and lack of palm trees. The Hartford Courant editorial board fired back in a feisty Wednesday editorial detailing Floridaâ€™s flaws and telling Scott to shove it: â€œHereâ€™s some advice for Florida Gov. Rick Scott: Go back to Florida and stay there â€¦ With all due respect, Mr. Scott, no thanks. Promises of a better climate and pictures of palm trees are nice, but thereâ€™s more to a state than its shrubbery. Peel the lemon, and the truth is obvious: Florida canâ€™t compare to Connecticut.â€

â€œTexts show Scottâ€™s influence over panelâ€™s recommendations for FDOT chiefâ€ via Matt Dixon of POLITICO Florida â€“ During the May 11 meeting, the Florida Transportation Commission â€” whose members are appointed by Scott â€” was ready to recommend three names. But the initial list of candidates did not include the Florida Department of Transportation chief of staff Mike Dew, the applicant Scott ultimately appointed secretary. â€œThe gov office is texting me to wait till [next] week,â€ Trumbull texted toward the end of the meeting to Commissioner Beth Kigel. â€¦ It was clear that the governorâ€™s influence was felt by members as they were discussing in the May 11 meeting when they should vote on their recommendations. In a text message to Trumbull, Commissioner John Browning said he was concerned that if the wrong decision was made, Scott would toss the recommendations and make the commission start over.

â€œScott asks for extension in judicial appointments lawsuitâ€ via Florida Politics â€” Scott asked the state Supreme Court for 14 extra days to respond to a lawsuit claiming he doesnâ€™t have the authority to appoint three new justices on the last day of his term. â€œThis motion is supported by good cause and is not opposed by petitioners,â€ says the motion by Scott general counsel Daniel Nordby. It asks to extend the filing deadline to July 19. Among the reasons cited: Legal briefings on bills still on the governorâ€™s desk and Scottâ€™s lawyersâ€™ â€œofficial duties associated with Section and Committee meetings at the 2017 Annual Bar Convention,â€ meeting in Boca Raton this week. Scott, a Naples Republican, has said he plans to name the replacements for the courtâ€™s liberal-leaning trio of Justices R. Fred Lewis, Barbara Pariente and Peggy A. Quince. They face mandatory retirement on the same day â€” Jan. 8, 2019 â€” that is Scottâ€™s last in office as governor. The lawsuit by The League of Women Voters of Florida and Common Cause says Scott canâ€™t replace those justices because heâ€™ll be out of office earlier on the same day all three retire, and their terms last till midnight.

Bill watch â€” Scott shot down two more bills Monday, bringing his total to six vetoes for 2017. The governor withheld his approval for SB 2512 on the Capitol Complex Advisory Council, and HB 5501 on â€œEconomic Programs.â€ On the proposed Council, Scott said in a veto letter it would â€œadd an unnecessary layer of red tape and bureaucracy.â€ On the economic programs bill, he said it was â€œmade obsolete by House Bill 1A,â€ passed during the recent Special Session and funding development and tourism marketing. Sixty-eight bills remain on the governorâ€™s desk.

SCOTT MAXWELLâ€™S TOUGH COLUMN

In a letter to the Orlando Sentinel, Cissy Proctor â€” the head of Scottâ€™s jobs division â€” took issue with a recent Scott Maxwell column saying Orlandoâ€™s wages â€œstink.â€ Proctor disagreed, saying Orlando wages are â€œhigher than 60 percent of our nationâ€™s metro areas.â€ Maxwell shot back, saying a comparison of â€œmetro areasâ€ wasnâ€™t apples-to-apples. Proctor didnâ€™t stick with similar sized communities or â€œeven close,â€ he writes.

Key Points from Maxwell:

â€” â€œRick Scott wants you to think heâ€™s created a stellar economy. And employers who pay poverty-level wages donâ€™t want to talk about that. But Iâ€™m not trying to spin. I just want to give you the honest numbers about wages. And the numbers show that Orlando wages stink.â€

â€” â€œIn a letter to the editor, Cissy Proctor â€” the head Gov. Rick Scottâ€™s jobs division â€” took issue with a column I wrote last month about Orlandoâ€™s low wages. I said our wages stink. Proctor disagreed, claiming Orlandoâ€™s wages help families â€˜flourishâ€™ and are â€˜higher than 60 percent of our nationâ€™s metro areas.â€™ That sounds good, doesnâ€™t it? Yet it also sounds completely at odds with everything this paper has ever reported. (â€˜Central Florida job metro area market is lowest-paying in countryâ€™ and â€˜Orlando: No. 1 in tourism, dead last in wagesâ€™).â€

â€” â€œThe facts, however, are that Orlando is still where this newspaper has long reported. Our wages are A) Way below the national average; and B) Rock bottom compared to other major metros. (50 out of 50 in median wages; 47th or 48th out of 50 in average wages, depending on the survey.)â€

â€” NOTES FROM THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL â€”

â€œScott remains tight-lipped about U.S. Senate bidâ€ via Florida Politics â€” Scott remains tight-lipped about his 2018 plans, telling CNN he wonâ€™t make any decision about the U.S. Senate race until a later date. â€œIâ€™ve always said the same thing: Itâ€™s 2017. The race is in 2018. I wonâ€™t make a decision until later,â€ said Scott during an interview with Erin Burnett on her show Erin Burnett OutFront. â€œPoliticians seem to worry about their next job. Iâ€™ve got 570 days to go in this job. Iâ€™m trying to make Florida No. 1 for jobs, No. 1 for people being safe â€¦ and No. 1 for education.â€ Scott is widely believed to be considering a U.S. Senate run in 2018. Democratic Sen. Bill Nelson has already said he plans to run for re-election.

Kirsten Gillibrand backs Gwen Graham for governor â€” The New York Democrat announced Tuesday she was endorsing Gwen Graham in her bid for governor. â€œI am proud to join thousands of others in supporting Gwen Graham, a strong progressive leader, for Governor of Florida. In the age of Trump, we need courageous leaders like Gwen who will always put people over politics and arenâ€™t afraid to stand up to anybody to do what is right,â€ said Gillibrand in a statement. â€œFor her strength and leadership skills, her fortitude and passion, I offer my strongest endorsement of Democrat Gwen Graham for Governor of Florida. Take it from me: with Gwen Graham as governor, Florida will have a champion for progressive values in the Governorâ€™s office.â€ The endorsement comes on the heels of the annual Leadership Blue Gala. Graham said Gillibrandâ€™s â€œsupport and the support of women from across the country who share our mission to turn Florida blue is humbling and drinking our campaign forward.â€

â€œChris King brings home his â€˜progressive entrepreneurâ€™ campaign messageâ€ via Scott Powers of Florida Politics â€” King â€¦ sought to distance himself from both his Democratic challengers, Tallahassee Mayor Andrew Gillum, and former U.S. Rep. Graham, as well as the Republicans. Itâ€™s a continuation of the â€œprogressive entrepreneurâ€ theme King initiated when he kicked off his campaign in Orlando two months ago. King criticizes Florida Republicans for overseeing a drop in inflation-adjusted wages and benefits, or doing nothing about it, and for, he said, leading Florida to place at the bottom of the nationâ€™s 10 most populous states in per capita income, productivity, gross domestic product, and mental health care services. â€¦ â€œYou can be a progressive, and believe in equality, and opportunity, and fairness, and justice, and care for the neediest among us. You can also marry that to entrepreneurship, to integrity, and hard work, and discipline, and stewardship. When those things are brought together, Iâ€™ve found in business it was a magical formula,â€ King said. â€œIn government, it can be a game-changer for the Democratic Party.â€

â€œRichard Corcoranâ€™s Watchdog PAC pulls in $608,000 in first month â€” including $100k from Norm Bramanâ€ via Mary Ellen Klas of the Miami Herald â€” The Braman gift, however, is telling as Corcoran is rumored to be using the PAC to position himself for higher office. Miamiâ€™s business leaders were in a serious tizzy in late April, when it appeared that Miami Rep. Jose Felix Diaz, the Houseâ€™s lead negotiator on a gambling bill, presented an offer to the Senate that indicated House leadership was prepared to overcome years of resistance and agree to authorize a new gaming facility in Miami-Dade. Braman joined health care executive Mike Fernandez, and Miami developer Armando Codina calling legislators enraged that they would move forward with the idea without understanding the impact it could have on the city, local businesses and the cityâ€™s successful economic boom. In less than a week, talks collapsed and the bill was declared dead. Corcoranâ€™s report, posted on his Watchdog PAC site, indicates he raised another $183,000 in donations of between $100 and $1,000 before his much-publicized fundraisers hosted by Orlando trial attorney John Morgan at the home of another Orlando trial attorney, Zander Clem.

Assignment editors: Adam Putnam will host an â€œUp & Adamâ€ breakfast with supporters at The Copper Monkey, 14209 West Newberry Road in Newberry.

â€œSimone Marstiller takes herself out of Attorney General contentionâ€ via Jim Rosica of Florida Politics â€” Former appellate judge and Republican Marstiller said on Facebook she will not run for Attorney General in 2018. â€œNOT running for AG,â€ she posted Monday night. â€œHolding that office has been a dream of mine for a long time. But Iâ€™ve reluctantly concluded that running for the office just isnâ€™t financially feasible for me. Thanks from the bottom of my heart to all of you for encouraging me and pledging your support. I am blessed beyond measure to have people like you in my life. The adventure continues â€¦â€ â€¦ Her name was first floated in a January post on The Capitolist by Brian Burgess, who included her among his picks to replace current Attorney General Pam Bondi amid rumors she was leaving to take a post in Trumpâ€˜s administration. Bondi is term-limited in 2018.

Ashley Moody endorsed by three Tampa Bay-area state Senators â€” Majority Leader Wilton Simpson, Sen. Tom Lee, and Sen. Dana Young have endorsed Moody in her race to replace Bondi in 2018, the Moody campaign announced Tuesday. â€œWe are proud to have the support of three of our stateâ€™s most trusted Republican leaders. They are not just leaders in Tallahassee, but in their respective communities,â€ said Moody in a statement.â€ They are champions for the common sense, conservative principles that have helped make our state a great place to live, work, vacation, and retire. Iâ€™m extremely thankful for their support and I hope to work with them in the years to come to continue to make Florida safer and stronger.â€ Moody, a Hillsborough County Republican, faces Jacksonville Republican Rep. Jay Fant in the Republican primary to replace Bondi.

Hillsborough County leaders back Moody for AG â€” Rep. Jackie Toledo, Hillsborough County Doug Belden, and Hillsborough County School Board member Melissa Snively announced they were endorsing Moody in the race to replace Bondi in 2018. Moody, a former Hillsborough circuit judge, said she was pleased to have their endorsements. â€œDoug works each and every day to save taxpayers money and make government more efficient and effective. He is recognized statewide as an outstanding Tax Collector and public servant. Iâ€™m so humbled to call him a friend and I thank him for his support,â€ she said in a statement. â€œThe well-being of our children and the quality of their education are top priorities of Melissa Snively. As a mother, I canâ€™t thank her enough for her dedication to our children and improving our public-school system. Representative Toledoâ€™s passion for public service is apparent to each and every person she meets. Her commitment to her constituents and making our community and state a better place sets a shining example for all public servants. Iâ€™m thankful for her leadership in Tallahassee and for the support of all of these outstanding elected officials.â€

â€œBernie Sanders isnâ€™t backing Tim Canova in his second bid against Debbie Wasserman Schultzâ€ via Alex Daugherty of the Miami Herald â€” Canova announced he will challenge Wasserman Schultz again in 2018 despite a 14-point loss in the Democratic primary to the longtime congresswoman from Weston. But this time around, Sanders isnâ€™t on board. â€œI have no idea about Tim Canova, I honestly donâ€™t,â€ Sanders said when asked if he plans to support Canovaâ€™s second bid against Wasserman Schultz. â€œI know nothing about Tim Canova.â€ Sanders declined to answer whether he thinks Wasserman Schultz should face a primary challenge from a more liberal-leaning Democrat. The Canova campaign said the lack of support from Sanders doesnâ€™t matter even though it could mean millions in contributions from supporters of the Vermont senator.

Florida Chamber endorses Jose Felix Diaz in SD 40 â€” The Florida Chamber of Commerce announced it was backing Diaz in the special election to replace Sen. Frank Artiles in Senate District 40. â€œRepresentative Jose Felix Diaz continues to put Florida families and businesses first, and has remained an advocate for free enterprise and job creation,â€ said Marian Johnson, the senior vice president of political strategy at the Florida Chamber of Commerce. â€œThe Florida Chamber is proud to endorse Representative Jose Felix Diaz for the Florida Senate.â€ Diaz faces former Sen. Alex Diaz de la Portilla and Lorenzo Palomares in the July special primary to replace Artiles, who resigned earlier this year amid scandal. â€œIf you ask the residents of District 40 what their biggest issues are â€” the answer is clear â€” jobs and the economy. The Florida Chamber of Commerce represents the biggest job creators in Florida, and I am honored to have their support for my State Senate race,â€ said Diaz in a statement. â€œI am proud of my record in support of low taxes and a responsible regulatory environment that both promotes sustained economic growth and protects consumers.â€

â€œRepublican rivals disagree on key issues in Miami Senate forumâ€ via Martin Vassolo of the Miami Herald â€” State Rep. Diaz and attorney Lorenzo Palomares told about 100 people gathered at Miami Dade College Kendall Campus where they stand on key issues. Primary candidates tend to have few differences â€” but not in this case. On recently passed education legislation known as House Bill 7069: Diaz supports it, Palomares doesnâ€™t. On a legislative deal to implement medical marijuana rules: Diaz supports it, Palomares doesnâ€™t. On the future of transit in Miami-Dade County: Diaz envisions autonomous vehicles, Palomares wants to expand the Dolphin Expressway past the western edge of the Urban Development Boundary. â€¦ Notably absent from the nevertheless largely amicable discussion was former state Sen. Alex Diaz de la Portilla, who is locked in a bitter campaign chiefly against Diaz.

â€œRepublican rivals in Miami House race are still trying to out-Cuban each otherâ€ via Patricia Mazzei of the Miami Herald â€” Foreign policy is not the purview of state lawmakers. Nevertheless, on Friday, after Trumpâ€™s East Little Havana event, candidate Jose Malleaâ€˜s campaign put out a robocall to House District 116 Republican voters touting Malleaâ€™s support for Trumpâ€™s policy shift. â€œMallea is a real Republican, Cuban-American, who wants to fight for a free Cuba,â€ the call said. â€œIn contrast, his opponent, Daniel Perez, was a beneficiary of the Obama-Castro policy, going to Cuba on a luxury vacation to take his engagement photos.â€ â€¦ Meantime, Perezâ€™s campaign was sending voters a letter, in English and Spanish, from Perezâ€™s parents, vouching for their sonâ€™s Cuban roots. The family left Cuba in 1969, Guelcys and Eugenio Perez wrote in their â€œpersonal message,â€ which also said Perezâ€™s uncle Antonio Perez â€œdied fighting against the Castro regime.â€ â€œThe truth is that Danny traveled to Cuba with his fiancee, Stephanie, to visit her sick uncle and her family,â€ they wrote. â€œDanny was NOT in Cuba as a tourist, as his opponent and The Miami Herald are attempting to falsely portray!!â€

â€œFour Republicans, one Democrat qualify to run in HD 44 special electionâ€ via Scott Powers of Orlando Rising â€” The Republicans who qualified are former Winter Garden Commissioner Bobby Olszewski, who ran in a similar region last year in an unsuccessful, but close, bid for Orange County commissioner; John Newstreet, president and chief executive officer of the Kissimmee/Osceola County Chamber of Commerce; businessman Bruno Portigliatti, and urgent care physician Dr. Usha Jain. Businessman Paul Chandler is the Democratsâ€™ candidate. Republicans may be looking ahead from this election. If a Republican wins, itâ€™ll give that person a yearâ€™s head-start on campaigning, fundraising, and collecting IOUs for the prospect of becoming Speaker of the House for the freshmen class of representatives whoâ€™ll new voted into office in 2018.

â€” â€œDemocrat Nuren Haider withdrawing from HD 44 special electionâ€ via Scott Powers of Orlando Rising

â€” â€œRepublican HD 44 candidate John Newstreet fundraiser claims $20Kâ€ via Scott Powers of Orlando Rising

Mark Lipton files to run in HD 79 â€” State records show Lipton has filed to run in House District 79 in 2018. Lipton filed the necessary paperwork to replace Rep. Matt Caldwell Monday. The North Fort Myers Democrat joins Republican Michelle Graham in the race to replace Caldwell, who canâ€™t run again in 2018 because of term limits.

â€œThe Miami Beach mystery PAC is under state investigationâ€ via Nicholas Nehamas, Joey Flechas and David Ovalle of the Miami Herald â€” A public-corruption probe is underway into a controversial political group linked to Miami Beach commissioner and mayoral candidate Michael Grieco â€¦ At least one donor to the political action committee has been subpoenaed by the Miami-Dade State Attorneyâ€™s Office, according to a Miami Beach defense attorney representing the donor â€¦ The list of donors to People for Better Leaders is stocked with Miami Beach vendors, lobbyists and developers with business before the city. The PAC raised $200,000 in 2016. Itâ€™s not clear how many of the 23 individuals and corporations that gave to People for Better Leaders received subpoenas. In the Beach, a violation of the cityâ€™s ethics ordinance is not a criminal offense, carrying just a small fine. If a commissioner or candidate solicited donations or coordinated with someone else to solicit on their behalf, a fine of $500 per violation would be issued, according to the city code.

â€œFormer police chief Jane Castor tops early poll looking at 2019 Tampa mayorâ€™s raceâ€ via Richard Danielson of the Tampa Bay Times â€” The automated telephone poll, commissioned by Tampa insurance executive Guy King and done by StPetePolls.org, surveyed 647 registered voters in Tampa. It had a 3.9 percent margin of error and a 95 percent confidence level. When respondents were asked if the election were held today and were given six names to choose from, they responded: Castor, 37.3 percent. Unsure, 29.1 percent. City Council member Mike Suarez, 9.7 percent. Former state Rep. Ed Narain and former Hillsborough County Commissioner Ed Turanchik, 7.7 percent each. City Council member Harry Cohen, 6.2 percent. Architect Mickey Jacob, 2.3 percent. King said he commissioned the poll because, â€œIâ€™ve seen the last few years how important having good leadership in the mayorâ€™s office is, (and) I started wondering, when our current mayor is gone, whoâ€™s going to fill those shoes?â€

â€œMajor project at the Vinoy will require St. Pete voter approvalâ€ via Janelle Irwin of the Tampa Bay Business Journal â€” A portion of the $50 million renovation plan will need voter approval before construction can begin. Hotel owners announced its one-story parking garage with eight tennis courts on the roof will go before voters for a vote Nov. 7 alongside St. Petersburg mayoral and City Council candidates. If approved, the garage would be built immediately behind the hotel where eight existing tennis courts are located. A 1984 city charter requires construction on historic locations in downtown St. Pete to receive voter approval. The garage wonâ€™t require taxpayer funding and will not change the hotelâ€™s overall footprint or impede on St. Peteâ€™s waterfront park system. It will provide approximately 270 new parking spaces for hotel guests, guests of on-site events, Vinoy facility members and people dining at one of the hotelâ€™s restaurants, which are open to nonmembers.

â€” STATEWIDE â€”

â€œWith no legislative action, Confederate statue remains in U.S. Capitolâ€ via Florida Politics â€” The General abides. With lawmakers taking no action this year, a bronze statue of a Confederate general representing Florida shall remain indefinitely in the U.S. Capitolâ€™s National Statuary Hall. Two competing bills died this Legislative Session. One called for a likeness of educator and civil rights activist Mary McLeod Bethune to replace the statue of Gen. Edmund Kirby Smith. Another proposed a statue of environmentalist Marjory Stoneman Douglas, author of â€œThe Everglades: River of Grass,â€ to take Smithâ€™s place. â€œNext year, we expect movement in the House and weâ€™ll pass it in the Senate,â€ said state Sen. Perry Thurston, who sponsored the Bethune measure. â€œI am encouraged we will get it done next year.â€

â€œDavid Simmons: Weâ€™re not done yet with HB 7069â€ via Scott Powers of Florida Politics â€” At a panel discussion, with three Republican state representatives, held by the Seminole County Chamber of Commerce, Simmons sharply criticized the â€œSchools of Hopeâ€ provisions in HB 7069, which he voted against, saying it is setting up underperforming public schools and their students to fail completely. â€œI donâ€™t think the book is completely written yet on this bill youâ€™ve probably all read about, House Bill 7069,â€ Simmons said. â€œIt was the amalgamation of at least 20 different subject matter issues that the house put into a bill. Various of us voted against it even though there were a lot of good things in it.â€ In particular, Simmons charged the Schools of Hope programâ€™s provision that requires schools with consecutive Ds or Fs to be shut down, move all the students to other schools, or create a â€œdistrict-operatedâ€ charter school, which essentially could not be run by the district.

â€œJoe Henderson: Dan Raulerson â€˜certainlyâ€™ not backing down after saying everyone should be armedâ€ via Florida Politics â€” Raulersonâ€™s remarks came during a forum at the Tampa Tiger Bay Club in response to a question about how the (Alexandria, Virginia) shooting impacted Florida and the nation. I asked him if he would say the same thing now if he had it to do over again. I got a one-word answer. â€œCertainly.â€ Then I got a lot more words. Raulerson isnâ€™t backing down from what said because, and this is important, he honestly believes itâ€™s the right thing to do. â€œHereâ€™s what I think people are misunderstanding,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m not suggesting we all walk around with 6-shooters in holsters and shoot everybody up. But had (Steve Scalise) not been on the ball field in Washington, there wouldnâ€™t have been two police officers there with guns. He was the only one with a security detail. Without those officers, it would have been a massacre. This isnâ€™t something Iâ€™m shying away from. We need to open our eyes and understand we live in a world that is vastly different from 15 years ago.â€

â€œTag, youâ€™re it: Latest state database â€˜slowdownâ€™ hinders motoristsâ€ via Steve Bousquet of the Tampa Bay Times â€” Floridaâ€™s fickle state-run driver database had more service interruptions Monday, and county tax collectors said they couldnâ€™t give motorists the service they deserve as taxpayers. But the system was back in full working order Tuesday morning. Monday was the first day that the Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles migrated to a new cloud-based solution as part of a long-term modernization of its decades-old databases. The agency said â€œslowdownsâ€ in its system affected only vehicle registrations. Driverâ€™s licenses, license renewals and vehicle titles were not affected and police had full access to its data, spokeswoman Beth Frady said. Why were only tag services affected? â€œWeâ€™re trying to get to the bottom of that,â€ Frady said.

â€œVisit Florida explains changes to local tourism groupsâ€ via Gabrielle Russon of the Orlando Sentinel â€” Visit Florida is sending a message to the stateâ€™s local tourism-marketing organizations when it comes to the financial disclosure rules that are intended to make public tax dollars more transparent: Call your attorney. Last week, Visit Florida held a call with the other local organizations to brief them as best they could and answer questions. Agency spokesman Stephen Lawson said they believe local organizations that receive 50 percent or more of revenue from bed taxes and also work with Visit Florida for marketing purposes will be required to disclose how much they pay their board of directors. The new changes were intended to reveal what â€” if anything â€” board members were paid for serving the tourism organizations, said Fred Piccolo, spokesman for House Speaker Corcoran who pushed for more transparency at Visit Florida.

â€” UP IN SMOKE â€”

â€œJohn Morgan ready to sue state over smokable potâ€ via Dara Kam of News Service Florida â€” â€œGreat Scott!! Iâ€™ll be filing my lawsuit for smoke as soon as it goes into law. Independence Day ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ #NoSmokeIsAJoke,â€ Morgan (@JohnMorganESQ) promised on Twitter â€¦ Morganâ€™s tweet references a quote from Scott, who pledged to sign into law a measure (SB 8A), passed by lawmakers during the special session that lays out the framework for the constitutional amendment, approved by more than 71 percent of voters in November. Morgan has vowed to sue over the issue of whether patients should be able to smoke the marijuana treatment. Despite Morganâ€™s threats, the proposal now awaiting Scottâ€™s signature bans smoking of marijuana, but it does allow patients to vape marijuana products. In a recent interview, Morgan said thatâ€™s not good enough.

â€œHealth Department getting started on medical marijuana rule-makingâ€ via Florida Politics â€” In the wake of the Special Sessionâ€™s implementing bill, the Florida Department of Health is gearing up to make rules governing the use of medical marijuana. The Department published a â€œnotice of proposed regulationâ€ in the Florida Administrative Register. But the state still could face a lawsuit from Morgan, who backed the constitutional amendment on medical marijuana that passed in 2016 with 71 percent of the vote. He has said he will sue because lawmakers would not allow medical marijuana to be smoked. The implementing bill (SB 8-A) is pending Gov. Scottâ€™s review, though he said he will sign it.

â€œLakeland scraps medical-marijuana dispensary rulesâ€ via Christopher Guinn of the Lakeland Ledger â€” Lakeland will scrap its medical-marijuana dispensary zoning ordinance in utero as the proposed language, which was slated for a vote July 5, contradicts rules created by the Florida Legislature in a special session. Under the rules approved by the Legislature and awaiting the governorâ€™s signature, cities and municipalities are not able to limit the location of medical-marijuana dispensaries more strictly than they do for pharmacies. The Lakeland ordinance that was up for second of two required readings in front of the public would have prevented the clustering of medical-pot shops, set a minimum proximity to houses of worship and allow them in only two types of building zones. Under the state legislation, cities and counties will be able to ban medical-marijuana dispensaries, but even the commissioners preferring stricter restrictions have not voiced the idea.

â€œTampaâ€™s Joe Redner wants to grow his own cannabis plants, says suitâ€ via Justine Griffin of the Tampa Bay Times â€” Tampaâ€™s outspoken strip club entrepreneur, Redner, wants to grow his own marijuana plants. So much so that heâ€™s filed a lawsuit against the Florida Department of Health, which under current rules bars Floridians from growing cannabis plants for their personal use, even those who are legally registered as medical marijuana patients. Redner, 77, is a registered patient in Florida and uses cannabis products to treat conditions related to his stage-four lung cancer. While he actively purchases cannabis oil products from local dispensaries, he says he wants the right to grow his own plants, according to the suit filed in Hillsborough County.

â€” SOBER HOMES IN THE SPOTLIGHT â€”

South Floridaâ€™s trials and tribulations with sober homes was in the spotlight this week after Lizette Alvarez with The New York Times looked at the impact opioid addiction â€” and the stateâ€™s sober home system â€” was impacting Palm Beach County.

According to the report, Delray Beach paramedics responded to 748 overdose calls last year, 65 of which ended in fatalities. All in told, Palm Beach County dealt with 5,000 overdose calls last year.
